title: 108_hr415
content: The "Congress 2006 Commission Act" establishes the "Congress 2006 Commission" with specific duties outlined for the Commission. The Commission established by the "Congress 2006 Commission Act" is tasked with analyzing the size of the House of Representatives, exploring alternative methods of electing Representatives, addressing the decline in adherence to political parties, and considering ways to increase citizen participation in the electoral process. The Commission established by the "Congress 2006 Commission Act" aims to include more citizens in the electoral process, propose changes in the House of Representatives' membership and election methods, and submit a report with legislative drafts by the end of the One Hundred Eighth Congress. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President, House of Representatives, and Senate. Appointees should be qualified in politics or government. Members serve for the Commission's duration, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President, House of Representatives, and Senate, who serve for the Commission's duration. Each member, other than full-time officers or employees of the United States, is paid the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule and receives travel expenses. Eight members constitute a quorum, with the Chairman elected by the members, and meetings called by the Chairman or a majority of members. SEC. 5. STAFF. The Chairman of the Commission may appoint up to six staff members without following standard government hiring procedures. These individuals can be paid up to the maximum rate for a GS-15 grade employee. Additionally, the Chairman can hire temporary services as needed at specified rates. The Commission can hire staff members at rates not exceeding the maximum annual rate for a GS-15 grade employee. Federal agencies can also detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 6. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission can hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can use the United States mails and receive administrative support services. SEC. 7. TERMINATION. The Commission will cease to exist when its report is submitted under section 3.
